p: The Sindbis virus (SIN) is an Alphavirus belonging to the WEEV complex that was first isolated from mosquitoes in Egypt and is one of the least pathogenic Alphaviruses known [ 90]. Chimeric SIN/EEEV, SIN/VEEV, and SIN/WEEV viruses have been investigated for use as live virus vaccines. In one study, Sindbis virus was used for the nonstructural genes, and the EEEV structural genes C-E3-E2-6K-E1 were derived from North American (NA) strain FL93-939 to create the vaccine SIN/NAEEEV [ 76]. After immunization with SIN/NAEEEV, mice developed high titers of neutralizing antibodies. Following challenge with FL93-939, 80â€“100% of mice vaccinated with SIN/NAEEV survived, depending on the vaccine dose. This vaccine was also evaluated in a cynomolgus macaque model with a lethal EEEV aerosol challenge [ 77]. Most (82%) SIN/NAEEEV vaccinated macaques survived with little evidence of disease.
